facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 125, 231 and 447 of 1960 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 125, 231 and 447 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated September 25, 1957, of Income-tax References Nos. 30, 29 and 37/57.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1957, of the Bombay High Court of Income-tax References Nos. 30, 29 37/57, respectively.

facts.text: Three appeals heard together with special leave of this Court.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals, with special leave of this Court have been heard together.

facts.text: Appeals arise out of Income-tax Reference No. 29 of 1957, Income-tax Reference No. 30 of 1957 and Income-tax Reference No. 37 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: They arise out of three Income-tax References made to the High Court of Bombay, namely, Income-tax Reference No. 29 of 1957, Income- tax Reference No. 30 of 1957 and Incometax Reference No. 37 of 1957.

facts.text: Nanalal Haridas was the karta of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: One Nanalal Haridas was the karta of a Hindu undivided family which admittedly was the beneficiary

facts.text: Hindu undivided family was the beneficiary of 1842 shares in Cotton Export and Import Limited.

anchor.surface_text: of a Hindu undivided family which admittedly was the beneficiary of 1842 shares in a companypany called the Cotton Export and Import Limited

facts.text: Shares held in names: 877 in Tribhuvandas Haridas, 815 in Nanalal Haridas, 150 in Nanalal Haridas and Tribhuvandas Haridas.

anchor.surface_text: The shares were held in the names of different members of the family as given below. No. of shares Name or names in which they stand 877 Tribhuvandas Haridas 815 Nanalal Haridas 150 Nanalal Haridas and Tribhuvandas Haridas

facts.text: Cotton Export and Import Limited was a company in which the public were substantially interested.

anchor.surface_text: The Company was one in which the public were number substantially interested.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, Income-tax Officer applied s. 23A of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as prior to 1955 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1949-50 the Income-tax Officer companycerned applied the provisions of s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  as it stood previous to the amendment of 1955

facts.text: Income-tax Officer ordered undistributed portion of assessable income deemed distributed as dividend among shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: and ordered that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the Company of the relevant previous year, as companyputed for income-tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and supper-tax payable by it in respect thereof, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend among the shareholders

facts.text: Proportionate dividend of 1842 shares, grossed up, Rs. 54,307/- added to income of joint family.

anchor.surface_text: Theproportionateamount of dividend of the 1842 shares, after being grossed up, came to Rs. 54,30,7/-. This amount the Income-tax Officer added to the income of the joint family.

facts.text: Assessee family claimed deemed dividend under s.23A should be assessed in hands of registered shareholders, not HUF.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee family claimed that the dividend deemed to have been distributed under s. 23A should be assessed in the hands of the shareholders, that is, the persons in whose names the, shares stood registered

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contention.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant,Commissioner rejected ,this companytention.

facts.text: Matter appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The matter them went in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Department contended before Tribunal that joint family is shareholder under s.23A.

anchor.surface_text: The Department companytended before the Tribunal that having regard to the scheme of s.23 A and the ordinary dictionary meaning of the word share holder, there was numberreason why the joint family should number be held to be the shareholder

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated February 15, 1957, allowed appeal, directed deletion of deemed dividend from HUF income, bound by Bombay HC in S.C. Cambatta.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its order dated February 15, 1957, expressed the view that the interpretation of s. 23A for which the assessee companytended would defeat the very purpose of that section, but held that it was bound by the decision of the Bombay High Court in S. C. Cambatta V. Commissioner of Income,-tax, Bombay  1 . Accordingly, the Tribunal allowed the appeal

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax moved Tribunal to refer question: Whether dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is to be assessed in hands of assessee HUF?

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, then moved the Tribunal to refer the following question of law to the High Court of Bombay Whether the dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee, the Hindu undivided family?

facts.text: Tribunal referred the question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was of the view that the question did arise out of its order and made a reference to the High Court accordingly.

facts.text: High Court by order dated September 25, 1957, answered question in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its order dated September 25, 1957, answered the question in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: High Court held HUF not registered shareholder, so deemed dividend not its income under s.23A.

anchor.surface_text: It held that in respect of an income which was deemed to be distributed under the provisions of s. 23A, the section in terms provided that the proportionate share of the shareholders in such distribution should be included in their income and as the Hindu undivided family was number and companyld number be a registered shareholder

facts.text: High Court reaffirmed S.C. Cambatta v. CIT Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court re-affirmed the view it had expressed in its earlier decision in S. C. Cambatta v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  1 .

facts.text: High Court refused leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused leave to appeal to this Court from its decision in question,

facts.text: Commissioner obtained special leave and filed appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: the Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay, applied to this Court for special leave and having obtained  1   1946  14 I.T.R. 748. such leave has brought these appeals to this Court.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family was not a registered shareholder of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the Hindu undivided family as such was number a shareholder of the companypany in the present case.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by K. DAS, J. on July 18, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. July, 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.

issues.text: Whether the dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee, the Hindu undivided family?

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, then moved the Tribunal to refer the following question of law to the High Court of Bombay Whether the dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is to be assessed in the hands of the assessee, the Hindu undivided family?

issues.text: Whether the expression 'shareholder' in s. 23A means the registered shareholder in the books of the company?

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, we see numberreason why the expression shareholder in s. 23A should number have the same meaning, namely, a shareholder registered in the books of the companypany.

issues.text: Whether a literal interpretation of 'shareholder' as registered holder in s. 23A defeats the purpose of the section to prevent avoidance of super-tax?

anchor.surface_text: It would be anomalous if the expression shareholder has one meaning in S. 18 5 and a different meaning in s. 23A of the Act for that would mean that a Hindu undivided family treated as a shareholder for the purpose of s. 23A would number be entitled to the benefit of s. 18 5 of the Act. The learned companynsel for the appellant has urged two points in support of his companytention that the expression shareholder in s. 23A means the person who owns the share, irrespective of the circumstance whether that person is registered in. the books of the companypany as a shareholder or number.

issues.text: Whether the legal fiction created by s. 23A must be carried to its logical conclusion to include assessment on the beneficial owner (HUF)?

anchor.surface_text: The question is really one of interpretation of s. 23A, and we must interpret s. 23A with reference to its own terms. The section in express terms says that the proportionate share of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of the shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The section does number talk of the beneficial owner of the share. It talks of the shareholder only.

holdings.text: The expression 'shareholder' in s. 23A means the shareholder registered in the books of the company.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, we see no reason why the expression shareholder in s. 23A should not have the same meaning, namely, a shareholder registered in the books of the company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with interpretation of 'shareholder' in s.18(5), ss.16(2), Companies Act 1913, and precedents like Cambatta, Shree Shakti Mills, Howrah Trading; harmonious construction avoids anomaly where HUF shareholder under s.23A denied s.18(5) benefits.

holdings.text: The dividend income of Rs. 54,307/- is not to be assessed in the hands of the assessee Hindu undivided family as it was not a registered shareholder.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court correctly answered the question which was referred to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HUF not registered shareholder per books; s.23A deems distribution to registered shareholders only; affirmed High Court and Tribunal (bound by Cambatta); applies plain terms to facts.

holdings.text: s. 23A in express terms requires inclusion of proportionate share in total income of the shareholder, not beneficial owner.

anchor.surface_text: The question is really one of interpretation of s. 23A, and we must interpret s. 23A with reference to its own terms. The section in express terms says that the proportionate share of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of the shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The section does not talk of the beneficial owner of the share.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.23A(1) specifies 'shareholder'; no mention of beneficial ownership; distinguished from 'owner of security' in s.18(5); sub-ss.(3),(4) refer to 'members' excluding HUF.

holdings.text: The legal fiction under s. 23A is restricted to the plain terms of the statute and cannot be extended to its logical conclusion beyond express language.

anchor.surface_text: The fiction enacted by the Legislature must be restricted by the plain terms of the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction creates notional dividend for registered shareholders only; cannot expand to beneficial owners or cure statutory lacuna via interpretation; rejects extension argument.

holdings.text: Literal interpretation confining s.23A to registered shareholders does not defeat the purpose of the section.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we see how it can be said that the interpretation put on s.23A that it is confined to a shareholder registered in the books of the company defeats the very purpose of the section. The section will still apply to shareholders of the company and to their income will be added the notional income determined under s. 23A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section achieves anti-avoidance goal for registered shareholders; purpose not frustrated as it still imposes super-tax liability on them; rejects purposive override of text.

holdings.text: A Hindu undivided family as such is not a member of the company under s.23A(3) and (4).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-sections (3) and (4) of s. 23A also make the position clear they talk of members of the company and a Hindu undivided family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language in sub-sections uses 'members'; HUF incapable of company membership consistent with company law and precedents.

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers the issue by stating that the expression 'shareholder' in s. 23A means the shareholder registered in the books of the company.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, we see no reason why the expression shareholder in s. 23A should not have the same meaning, namely, a shareholder registered in the books of the company.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court correctly answered the question which was referred to it.

anchor.surface_text: idered by this Court in Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay  1  and Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Nandlal Gandalal  ? . It

anchor.surface_text: The question is really one of interpretation of s. 23A, and we must interpret s. 23A with reference to its own terms. The section in express terms says that the proportionate share of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of the shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income. The section does not talk of the beneficial owner of the share.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court correctly answered the question which was referred to it.

edges.explanation: h4 states that the legal fiction under s.23A is restricted to plain terms and cannot be extended to logical conclusion, directly grounding the doctrine

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we see how it can be said that the interpretation put on s.23A that it is confined to a shareholder registered in the books of the company defeats the very purpose of the section. The section will still apply to shareholders of the company and to their income will be added the notional income determined under s. 23A.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court correctly answered the question which was referred to it.
For these reasons we are of the view that the High Court correctly answered the question which was referred to it.
